Carbon deposition is an important cause of rapid deactivation of nickel-based catalysts during dry reforming of methane. Catalyst precursors were synthesized by CAB (cocamidopropyl betaine) assisted impregnation and subsequently activated via calcination (NM-CAB-1/50-C) and RF plasma (NM-CAB-PN2h), respectively. The catalyst was characterized using XRD, CO2-TPD, FTIR, XPS, UV, TEM, H2-TPR and TG-DTA. Compared to NM-C, NM-CAB-1/50-C exhibited an enhancement of 13.14 % and 11.01 % in the initial conversion rates of CH4 and CO2 respectively. The carbon deposition of NM-CAB-1/50-C post-reaction (3.43 %) was markedly lower than that of NM-C (23.38 %), indicating that the CAB improved the catalyst's activity and resistance to carbon deposition to a certain degree. Specifically, NM-CAB-PN2h had the greatest activity and most potent anti-carbon deposition capability among all the catalysts. For NM-CAB-PN2h, the initial conversion rates of CH4 and CO2 attained 82.53 % and 85.71 %, respectively, with a carbon deposition level of merely 0.7 % post-reaction. The characterization results indicated that NM-CAB-PN2h exhibited the smallest nickel particle size (4.2 nm) and the most robust metal-support interaction force. The catalyst demonstrated a significant surface adsorbed oxygen concentration of 7.3 %. This results from the synergistic effect of CAB and N2 plasma, which markedly diminishes the size of active metal particles, amplifies the metal-support contact force, and elevates the alkalinity of the catalytic surface along with the surface-adsorbed oxygen content. Consequently, the catalyst's activity and resistance to carbon deposition were markedly improved. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dry reforming of methane Cocamidopropyl betaine Nickel-based catalysts Carbon resistance Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the continuous utilization of fossil fuels, the requirement for clean alternative energy sources is on the rise. In the current research, syngas has an important impact on the production of clean energy, such as the purification of hydrogen from syngas and the production of fuel cells [1]. Also syngas can be directly used in chemical synthesis such as Fischer-Tropsch synthesis [2–4]. Syngas is a mixture of CO and H2, and the main feedstock to produce syngas is CH4, which is produced in two main ways, steam reforming of methane (SRM) [5–7]an dry reforming of methane carbon dioxide (DRM) [8–10]. Compared to SRM [11], syngas produced by dry reforming of methane is more important for industry. Methane dry reforming reduces the pollution of two greenhouse gases, requires less activation energy and has a simpler reaction system. DRM is based on CH4 and CO2 to produce syngas with a 1:1 molar ratio of H2 and CO [12,13]. The reaction mechanism is based on the following four reactions [14,15]. Eq. (1) is the main methane dry reforming reaction, Eq. (2) is the inverse water gas reaction, and Eqs. (3) and 4 are carbon deposition reactions that should be inhibited throughout the DRM reaction [16]. (1) C H 4 + C O 2 ↔ 2 CO + 2 H 2 Δ H 298 θ = 247 kJ · mo l − 1 (2) C O 2 + H 2 ↔ CO + H 2 O Δ H 298 θ = 41 kJ · mo l − 1 (3) C H 4 ↔ C + 2 H 2 Δ H 298 θ = 75 kJ · mo l − 1 (4) 2 CO ↔ C + C O 2 Δ H 298 θ = − 172 kJ · mo l − 1 The DRM reaction is a strongly heat-absorbing reaction, and loaded catalysts are usually used to improve the conversion of DRM [17,18]. The commonly used active components in loaded catalysts are mainly noble metals (e.g., Pt, Ru, Ir, etc.), but because precious metals are expensive, transition metals (e.g., Ni, Co, etc.) have received extensive attention. Nickel-based catalysts are the most commonly used transition metal catalysts for DRM. However, the active metal Ni is prone to sintering at high temperatures. This results in a decrease in the number of active sites, the rapid accumulation of carbon from the cracking of methane that cannot be eliminated, and the rapid deactivation of the catalyst [19]. Accordingly, the development of efficient and stable nickel-based catalysts is imminent. Recently, many researchers have found that reducing the size of active metal particles can significantly improve the performance of nickel-based catalysts [20]. As an effective means, Surfactant can be used as a structure-directing agent to adjust the size of metal particles and thus enhance catalyst performance [21]. Lei et al [22]. prepared nickel-based catalysts for fatty acid methyl ester conversion reaction using CTAB to help reduce the size of metal particles. The results indicated that the catalyst prepared by adding CTAB had a better catalytic effect in the reaction and could maintain a small particle size for a long time without agglomeration. Wang et al [23]. prepared several Ni/Ce catalysts using CTAB as a template and tested their effectiveness in the decomposition of acetic acid with steam. The results showed that CTAB induced better Ni dispersion and smaller Ni size, and the hydrogen yield of Ni/Ce-C6 was 82.5 % at 550 °C. In addition to CTAB, other structure-directing agents such as cocamidopropyl betaine (CAB) have also been shown to be effective in controlling the size of metal particles [24]. Andrey V. Blinov et al [25]. prepared selenium nanoparticles using CAB that were more stable and relatively smaller in size. Specifically, the size of selenium nanoparticles was reduced by 50 % using CAB, which significantly improved the stability of selenium nanoparticles in different pH solutions. Therefore, CAB can effectively limit the size of nanoparticles, which improves the performance and anti-coking ability of nano-catalysts. Consequently, the addition of CAB in the preparation of DRM nano-catalysts is a novel and convenient method. Due to its novel technique, plasma technology has garnered significant attention in the field of catalyst preparation in recent years [26]. For instance, Di et al [27]. prepared Ru-based supported catalysts using cold plasma technology and applied them to the methanation of CO2. The carbon dioxide conversion of Ru/γ-Al2O3 prepared by the plasma method was higher at 76.3 % compared to the conventional thermal reduction method. Lee et al [28]. made Ni-CeO2 catalysts using radio frequency thermal plasma and checked how well they worked for partially oxidizing methane. The results indicated that the methane conversion rate exceeded 70 %, with CO and H₂ selectivity both over 90 %, and only slight carbonization was observed during the online test at 550 °C for 24 h. Dai et al [29]. prepared Ni/CeZrO2 catalyst precursor by co-precipitation method, and then treated it with cold plasma and used it in methane dry reforming reaction. The carbon deposition rate of Ni/CeZrO2 was found to be only 4.5 % by TGA-DSC. This is because a radiofrequency electric field causes N₂ gas to form high-density, high-energy electrons, N₂⁺ ions, excited-state N₂*, and active nitrogen atoms (N). The N₂⁺ ions are then accelerated by the sheath potential difference and strike the surface of the Ni particles with a kinetic energy ranging from tens to hundreds of electron volts [26]. This process of momentum transfer causes the surface nickel particles to break and undergo physical sputtering, with the sputtered small Ni particles becoming randomly distributed on the surface of the support. The continuous bombardment of ions and the resulting atomic-level erosion of the material occur uniformly throughout the particle, causing the Ni particles to thin layer by layer from the surface to the interior. This ultimately results in a significant reduction in particle size. Additionally, the high energy of the N₂ plasma promotes the dispersion of small metal ions on the support. Therefore, plasma technology has been shown to be a new and simple method to fabricate DRM nano-catalysts, which can improve the performance of the catalysts by controlling the size of the metal particles, but there still exists some room for enhancement. Traditional supported nickel-based catalysts exhibit low activity and severe coking during methane dry reforming. This study therefore used MCM-41 as a support due to its high specific surface area, uniform mesoporous structure and high stability. The structure-directing agent CAB was added during the impregnation process and the catalyst was bombarded with N2 radio frequency plasma. The catalyst was tested at 700 °C and characterized using XRD, TEM, CO2-TPD, FTIR, UV, XPS, H2-TPR, and TG-DTA. The focus was on evaluating how synergy between CAB and plasma affects the structure, reforming activity and carbon resistance of the nickel-based catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The conventional catalyst NM-C was prepared as follows: the nickel loading of the fixed catalyst was 10 wt. %. Specifically, 0.991 g of nickel nitrate is added to 30 mL of deionized water and stirred until dissolved. Subsequently, 1.8 g of MCM-41 was added and stirred thoroughly. The resulting solution was macerated at room temperature for 45 min and then transferred to a water bath at 80 °C to dry until a green powder was formed. It was then dried twice in a vacuum oven at 110 °C for 12 h. The resulting precursor was calcined in air at 550 °C for 4 h to obtain the conventional catalyst NM-C. NM-CAB-x-C was prepared as follows: it was prepared in the same way as the conventional catalyst NM-C. The only difference is the addition of different amounts of CAB (n(CAB)/n(Ni) = 1/20, 1/50, 1/70) during the dissolution of nickel nitrate. RF plasma modified conventional catalyst only: The conventional catalyst precursor was treated in a radio frequency (RF) plasma generator for 2 h to obtain NM-PN2h. RF plasma synergistic CAB-modified nickel-based catalyst: The prepared precursor with CAB/Ni molar ratio of 1:50 was subjected to radiofrequency plasma treatment in N2 atmosphere for 2 h, and the final catalyst NM-CAB-PN2h was obtained. 2.2 Catalyst evaluation A certain amount of prepared catalyst mixed with a small amount of quartz sand was put into the quartz tube of the continuous flow fixed-bed reactor, and the catalyst was fixed in the middle of the glass tube with high-temperature quartz cotton and quartz sand, and the two ends of the quartz tube were installed vertically in the reactor. The catalyst was subjected to H2 reduction in a resistance furnace at 700 °C for 1.5 h under the following conditions: H2 gas flow rate of 16 mL∙min−1 and heating rate of 10 °C/min. After the catalyst was cooled down to ambient temperature, the catalyst was introduced to a mixture of CH4 and CO2 with a gas flow rate of GHSV = 36,000 mL/g −1∙h −1. After the flow rate stabilized, the reactor was heated up to 700 °C for 20 h at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The conversion of CH4 and CO2, the yield of CO and the ratio of CO/H2 were calculated by the following formula. (5) C H 4 C o n v e r s i o n = F C H 4 , i n − F C H 4 , o u t F C H 4 , i n × 100 % (6) C O 2 C o n v e r s i o n = F C O 2 , i n − F C O 2 , o u t F C O 2 , i n × 100 % (7) C O Y i e l d = F C O , o u t F C O 2 , i n + F C H 4 , i n × 100 % (8) H 2 C O = C H 2 , o u t C C O , o u t where Fin and Fout are the volume flow rates of the gas at the inlet and outlet, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystalline state of the catalysts was analyzed using an X-ray instrument (XRD, Cu Kα source) with a scanning range of 10°−90° and a scanning speed of 2°∙min−1 . A BSD-Chem 200 instrument (H2-TPR/CO2-TPD) was used to check the reducibility of the catalysts. The catalyst was allowed to be treated at 300 °C for 30 min under argon, and then heated up to 800 °C for 30 min at a ramp rate of 10 °C /min under 10 % H2/Ar. The CO2/TPD determination of catalyst surface alkalinity was also carried out using a BSD-Chem 200 instrument. Infrared spectroscopic analysis of the catalyst surface functional groups was carried out using an IRTracer-100 spectrometer with a resolution of 4 cm−1 over a test interval of 400 - 4000 cm−1. The catalysts were analyzed by UV–visible testing using a UV-2700i instrument, starting with a substrate removal test with barium sulphate and using the Kubelka-Munk function to plot the UV absorption spectra and analyze the chemical state of nickel in the wavelength range of 200 nm-800 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific KAlpha+) was used to detect the binding energy and the distribution of different elemental contents in the catalyst. The morphology and structure of the catalysts were recorded using transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEMF200, Japan) and the distribution of various elements was examined using EDS. Carbon deposition on the catalyst after the reaction was measured using a STA2500 Thermogravimetric Analyzer at a temperature range of 50 °C-800 °C in an air atmosphere at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of fresh catalysts 3.1.1 XRD analysis Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of all catalysts before and after reduction. According to Fig. 1(a), all catalysts showed NiO diffraction peaks of varying intensities at 37.35°, 43.39°, 63.08°, 75.54°and 79.63° (PDF # 47–1049). After the introduction of CAB and plasma modification, the intensities of the five characteristic peaks around NiO were reduced to different degrees, indicating that CAB and plasma effectively improved the dispersion of NiO, which was very favorable for improving the activity of the catalyst. According to Fig. 1(b), the intensity of the metal Ni diffraction peaks of the modified catalyst also showed a similar decreasing trend as that of NiO, which indicated that the particle size of Ni gradually decreased after modification. Therefore, Table 1 calculates the particle size of all catalysts Ni separately using Scherrer's equation. The metal Ni sizes of the catalysts were in the order of NM-CAB-PN2h (4.2 nm) < NM-PN2h (5.5 nm) < NM-CAB-1/50-C (7.0 nm) < NM-CAB-1/70-C (7.5 nm) < NM-CAB-1/20-C (8.1 nm) < NM-C (18.1 nm). The results showed that when the CAB content was 1/50, the particle size was only 7.0 nm. This was because the low concentration of CAB was insufficient to disperse the Ni particles, while too high a concentration would block the support channels, preventing the Ni particles from entering and causing them to agglomerate into large particles. Interestingly, the Ni particle size in NM-CAB-PN2h was only 4.2 nm. This is attributed to the fact that CAB promotes the dispersion of NiO on MCM-41, allowing more NiO to be bombarded by the RF plasma, resulting in the formation of smaller metal particles. Relevant studies have shown that small particle size Ni species can effectively improve catalyst activity and inhibit carbon deposition during the reaction process [20]. Therefore, the synergistic effect of the structure-directing agent CAB and plasma can effectively reduce the size of the metal particles, thus improving the reforming activity and carbon deposition resistance of the catalyst. 3.1.2 H2-TPR analysis Fig. 2 characterizes the reducibility and interaction forces of all catalysts using H2-TPR. The reduction peaks of the catalysts at 250–450 °C and 450–550 °C were attributed to the reduction of NiO on the carrier surface and the reduction of NiO in the carrier skeleton, which corresponded to the weak and strong metal-carrier interaction forces, respectively [30]. While the reduction peak at 550–700 °C is due to the reduction of nickel silicate, which is attributed to the strong interaction force generated by Ni-O-Si copolymerization [31,32]. The reduction peaks of the CAB-modified catalysts were generally shifted towards higher temperatures and produced reduction peaks at 580 °C compared to NM-C. This suggests that CAB promotes the generation of Ni-O-Si copolymerization and the metal-support interaction force of the catalyst is enhanced. After the introduction of plasma coupled with CAB, the intensity of the nickel silicate reduction peak of NM-CAB-PN2h at 596 °C increased, which indicates that the synergistic effect of plasma and structure-directing agent CAB enhances the degree of Ni-O-Si copolymerization and improves the metal-support interaction force of the catalyst. Compared with NM-PN2h, the reduction peak of NM-CAB-PN2h disappeared at 293 °C, indicating that there was no reduction of free NiO in the catalyst. This was due to the synergistic effect of CAB and plasma, which promoted the binding of free NiO to the support. In addition, Table 2 shows the H2 consumption during catalyst reduction. Surprisingly, among all the catalysts, the H2 consumption of NM-CAB-PN2h reaches 1.1393 mmol·g −1, which indicates that the synergistic effect of structure-directing agent CAB and plasma effectively improves the reducibility of NiO. The increase in reducibility favors the activity of the catalyst, while the strong metal-support interaction significantly reduces the active metal agglomeration at high temperatures and improves the stability of the catalyst [33,34]. 3.1.3 CO2-TPD analysis CO2-TPD was used to investigate the surface alkalinity and CO2 adsorption capacity of all the catalysts and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . The absorption peaks at 50–200 °C corresponded to the weakly basic sites of the catalysts, while those at 200–600 °C and 600–800 °C corresponded to the moderately and strongly basic sites, respectively [29]. Compared with NM-C, the CAB-modified catalyst showed enhanced absorption peak intensities at three basic sites, which indicated that the CAB-modified catalyst had more basic sites and stronger CO2 adsorption capacity. And after plasma treatment, the NM-CAB-PN2h catalyst showed a significant increase in the intensity of the absorption peaks at the moderately basic sites and strongly basic sites, which exhibited excellent CO2 adsorption and activation properties [35]. Interestingly, NM-CAB-PN2h exhibits a shoulder peak at 592 °C, which is attributed to the adsorption peak induced by strongly basic sites generated through the synergistic effect of CAB and plasma [36]. In addition, the CO2 adsorption of the catalysts was calculated as shown in Table 2. Notably, NM-CAB-PN2h showed the highest CO2 adsorption, which was contributed to by the synergistic effect of the structure-directing agent CAB and the plasma, which effectively enriched the basic sites on the catalyst surface and enhanced the adsorption of CO2 on the catalyst. Relevant literature suggests that catalyst activity and resistance to carbon deposition are related to the adsorption and dissociation properties of CO2 [37]. Overall, NM-CAB-PN2h exhibited better CO2 adsorption with superior reforming activity and carbon accumulation resistance. 3.1.4 FT-IR analysis Fig. 4 FTIR tests in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 were performed for all catalysts. All catalysts exhibit absorption peaks at 462 cm⁻¹, 1083 cm⁻¹, 954 cm⁻¹, and 805 cm⁻¹, corresponding to the tetrahedral bending vibration of Si-O-Si, the symmetric stretching vibration of Si-O-Si within the framework, the stretching vibration of Si-O in the Si-OH group, and the asymmetric stretching vibration of Si-O-Si, respectively. 1638 cm⁻¹, 3451 cm⁻¹, and 1222 cm⁻¹ correspond to the bending vibration of OH, the stretching vibration of the carboxyl group, and the antisymmetric stretching vibration of Ni-O-Si [38–40]. Compared with NM-C, the peak intensities of the CAB-modified catalysts were reduced to varying degrees. This was attributed to the fact that CAB increased the dispersion of metallic nickel on the support, promoted the bonding of Ni-O-Si, and led to the weakening of the vibrations of Si-O-Si and Ni-O-Si. After the introduction of plasma treatment, the absorption peak intensities of the Si-O-Si group and Ni-O-Si were further reduced. This suggests that using plasma enhances the copolymerization of Ni-O-Si and thus promotes the metal-support interaction force, which is similar to the findings of H2-TPR. Surprisingly, the intensity of the absorption peak generated by the Si-O-H stretching vibration at 1387 cm−1 is increased for NM-CAB-PN2h. Because of the synergistic effect of structure-directing agent CAB and plasma to form defects on the support surface, causing O in the support skeletons to be released to form surface hydroxyl groups. Surface hydroxyl groups can be readily activated to adsorb oxygen to boost the resistance of the catalyst to carbon deposition [41]. 3.1.5 UV analysis Fig. 5 shows the UV spectral analysis of all catalysts in the 200–800 nm range. The strong UV absorption bands at 250–350 nm of the catalysts are due to the charge transfer from O2− to Ni2+ in NiO, while the weak UV absorption bands at 380 nm are mainly due to the charge transfer from octahedral O2− to Ni2+ in the NiO lattice [42,43]. The weaker intensity of the absorption peaks at 250–350 nm for the CAB-modified catalysts compared to NM-C indicates a reduced number of NiO clusters in the catalysts, which is attributed to the enhanced dispersion of Ni species by CAB. Upon plasma introduction, NM-CAB-PN2h produced an absorption peak at 206 nm, which corresponds to the charge transfer from O2− to Ni2+ in Ni-O-Si [44]. The disappearance of the absorption peak at 280 nm is attributed to the plasma effect leading to the entry of Ni into the support skeleton and the absence of NiO on the catalyst surface. This suggests that the synergistic effect of the structure-directing agent CAB and plasma promotes the formation of Ni-O-Si in the catalyst, which is conducive to increasing the metal-support interaction force. 3.1.6 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy XPS characterization was used to study the changes in the elemental composition and valence distribution of the catalysts due to the synergistic interaction of CAB and plasma, and the results are shown in Fig. 6 and Table 3 . In Fig. 6(a), the peaks at about 855 eV and 857 eV correspond to the Ni 2p3/2 orbitals, while the peak near 863 eV belongs to the satellite peaks of Ni2+ [45]. The Ni species peaks in the CAB-modified catalysts were shifted towards high binding energies compared to NM-C. After further plasma treatment, the Ni species peaks were shifted towards higher binding energies. According to Table 3, the Ni species peak of NM-CAB-PN2h has the highest binding energy, which indicates that this catalyst has the strongest metal-support interaction. Fig. 6(b) shows the O 1 s spectra of the catalysts. All catalysts showed peaks at approximately 530.8 eV, 532.8 eV and 534.7 eV, corresponding to Ni-O, Si-O and Oα, respectively [46]. According to Table 3, the adsorbed oxygen content on the surface of CAB-modified catalysts increased compared to NM-C, and the adsorbed oxygen content increased significantly after further plasma treatment. This is due to the synergistic effect of structure-directing agent CAB and plasma to form defects on the catalyst surface, releasing some of the lattice oxygen in the MCM-41 skeleton, which increased the surface adsorbed oxygen of the catalyst. Relevant studies have shown that the presence of adsorbed oxygen on the surface accelerates carbon elimination and reduces carbon deposition on the catalyst during the reaction process [47]. 3.1.7 TEM analysis results Fig. 7 shows the particle size and morphology of the catalysts characterized using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). In Fig. 7(a), the NM-C catalysts exhibit a distinct two-dimensional framework structure where the darker colored regions correspond to agglomerated nickel oxide particles with an average particle size of 18.3 nm. In contrast, the dispersion of nickel oxide particles in the CAB-treated (Fig. 7(b)) and plasma-treated (Fig. 7(c)) catalysts was significantly improved, with less agglomeration. Notably, Fig. 7(d) shows that there is no nickel oxide aggregation at all in the catalysts synergistically modified by CAB and plasma. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping analyses of NM-CAB-1/50-C (Figures. g, h, i) and NM-CAB-PN2h (Figures. j, k, l) confirmed the homogeneous distribution of Ni, Si and O elements. Comparative analyses showed that the NM-CAB-PN2h catalyst had a better nickel oxide dispersion with no obvious particle aggregation compared to NM-CAB-1/50-C. Quantitative particle size analyses of the four catalysts showed the following order of nickel particle size (from smallest to largest) NM-CAB-PN2h (4.3 nm) < NM-PN2h (5.6 nm) < NM-CAB-1/50-C (7.0 nm) < NM-C (18.3 nm). This trend is highly similar to the results of XRD characterization. It is confirmed that the synergistic effect of structure-directing agent CAB and plasma treatment effectively promotes the formation of small-sized nickel particles and enhances their dispersion on the MCM-41 support. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the catalysts To investigate the influence of the synergistic effect of structure-directing agent CAB and plasma on the reforming reaction performance of nickel-based catalysts, the prepared catalysts were tested for 20 h of DRM reaction at a reaction condition of 700 °C [48], as shown in Fig. 8 . According to Fig. 8 and Table 4 , it can be seen that the initial conversion of CH4 and CO2 of NM-C was only 60.05 % and 65.76 %, and the final conversion of CH4 and CO2 was 29.42 % and 43.97 %, respectively, after the reaction for 20 h, and the decrease of the activity was as high as 50.90 % and 55.49 %. After the addition of CAB, the reaction stability and initial activity of the catalyst were improved to a certain extent. Compared with NM-C, the initial conversion of CH4 and CO2 of NM-CAB-1/50-C was increased by 13.14 % and 11.01 %, respectively, and the activity decay rate was significantly reduced, which indicated that the stability of the catalyst was improved. Especially, the activity of the catalyst was greatly improved by the introduction of plasma treatment, and the initial CH4 and CO2 conversion of NM-CAB-PN2h reached an amazing 82.53 % and 85.71 %, respectively. Compared with NM-C, the initial CH4 and CO2 conversion of NM-CAB-PN2h increased by 22.53 % and 19.60 %, respectively. In addition, the decay rates of CH4 and CO2 activities of NM-CAB-PN2h were only 15.35 % and 11.72 %, which indicated that NM-CAB-PN2h had superior stability and better carbon accumulation resistance. 3.3 Characterization of spent catalysts 3.3.1 XRD analysis of spent catalysts The XRD characterization results of each catalyst after the reaction are shown in Fig. 9 . Among them, all catalysts showed three Ni crystalline diffraction peaks located at 44.50°, 51.86° and 76.39°, respectively. Compared to NM-C, the Ni diffraction peaks of the catalysts modified by both CAB and plasma were significantly reduced and no sharp graphitic carbon peaks were detected at 27.1°, which was attributed to the fact that the Ni did not undergo severe sintering after the reaction and no carbon deposition was generated during the reaction. Therefore, the particle size of the reacted metal Ni was calculated in Table 5 using the Scherrer's equation. The size of Ni particles after reaction was in the order of NM-CAB-PN2h (7.1 nm) < NM-PN2h (7.9 nm) < NM-CAB-1/50-C (8.5 nm) < NM-CAB-1/70-C (8.9 nm) < NM-CAB-1/20-C (10.5 nm) < NM-C (24.3 nm). Surprisingly, NM-CAB-PN2h remained the smallest particle size after the reaction at 7.1 nm, which indicated that no significant agglomeration of the active metal occurred during the reaction. This is the result of the synergistic effect of structure-directing agent CAB and plasma to improve the metal-support interaction force and inhibit the migration of metal Ni in the high-temperature environment, which improves the activity of the catalyst. 3.3.2 TG-DTA analysis of spent catalysts Fig. 10 and Table 6 show the TG-DTA analysis of the catalysts after the reaction. According to Fig. 10(a), all mass losses in the 50–100 °C range are attributed to the loss of moisture in the catalyst. The mass increase in the 300–400 °C temperature range is attributed to the oxidation of metallic nickel by air in the purge gas, while the mass loss in the 450–700 °C range is attributed to the loss of carbon deposits produced by the DRM reaction [49]. According to Table 6, the weight loss of NM-C in the 450–700 °C range is 23.38 %. Compared with NM-C, the weight loss of the CAB-modified catalyst was significantly lower, indicating that CAB can effectively reduce the carbon deposition in the reaction. After the introduction of plasma, the weight loss was further reduced, indicating that plasma can reduce the carbon deposition of catalysts [50,51]. Especially, the weight loss of NM-CAB-PN2h was the smallest, only 0.70 %, which may be attributed to the synergistic effect of the structure-directing agent CAB and the plasma to form surface defects on the catalyst surface, which increased the surface alkalinity and adsorbed oxygen content of the catalyst, inhibiting the formation of carbon deposition during the reaction process. 4 Discussion The nickel-based catalysts are prone to carbon deposition during dry reforming of methane (DRM) reactions leading to catalyst deactivation. Therefore, it is necessary to improve the activity and anti-carbon deposition properties of nickel-based catalysts. To address this, a precursor for the nickel-based catalyst was prepared using the CAB-assisted impregnation method, followed by treatment with radio Frequency (RF) plasma. The study investigated the synergistic impact of the structure-directing agent CAB and RF plasma on the catalyst performance. Reports in the literature indicate that the smaller the size of the active metal, the higher the activity of the catalyst [52,53]. Reaction data reveal that NM-CAB-PN2h exhibits higher initial conversion rates for CH4 and CO2 compared to NM-CAB-1/50-C and NM-PN2h, which indicates that the NM-CAB-PN2h catalyst has the smallest Ni particle size. This conclusion is in high agreement with the results of the XRD (Fig. 1) and TEM (Fig. 8) analyses, showing that the Ni crystal size of NM-CAB-PN2h is only 4.2 nm, significantly lower than the Ni particle sizes of NM-CAB-1/50-C (7.0 nm) and NM-PN2h (5.6 nm). This indicates that the synergistic effect of CAB and plasma further reduces the size of the metal species. According to related studies, the smaller the Ni particles, the more dispersed they are on the carrier surface, and the more active sites they produce [54]. Furthermore, the more CO2 a catalyst can adsorb, the higher its catalytic activity [47]. Combined with CO2-TPD analysis, NM-CAB-PN2h shows the most significant adsorption at medium and strong basic sites. Therefore, NM-CAB-PN2h demonstrates good catalyst activity The synergistic effect of CAB and plasma not only enhances the catalyst activity but also improves its stability. Studies have shown that the stronger the metal-support interaction in a catalyst, the greater its stability [55]. Reaction data indicate that after 20 h of reforming reaction, NM-CAB-PN2h exhibits the smallest decrease in CH4 and CO2 conversion rates, demonstrating its superior stability. Combining TPR, FTIR, and UV analyses, it is evident that NM-CAB-PN2h has the strongest metal-support interaction, suggesting that the synergistic effect of structure-directing agent CAB and plasma has strengthened the interaction between Ni and MCM-41 in the catalyst. The stronger the interaction between nickel and MCM-41, the less likely it is that the metal will sinter at high temperatures, thus reducing the likelihood of carbon deposition [53]. This is confirmed by the post-reaction XRD results, where the active metal particle size of NM-CAB-PN2h is only 7.1 nm. With less carbon accumulation, the deactivation rate of the catalyst is significantly reduced, enhancing its stability. Consistent conclusions can be drawn from post-reaction TG-DTA analysis. The carbon accumulation in NM-CAB-PN2h is merely 0.7 %, significantly lower than that in NM-CAB-1/50-C (3.43 %) and NM-PN2h (3.64 %). This indicates that the synergistic effect of CAB and plasma significantly improves the ability of the catalyst to resist carbon deposition. The XPS results further support this, showing that NM-CAB-PN2h has the highest surface adsorbed oxygen content, which is beneficial for the elimination of carbon accumulation during the reaction process. This is also the reason why NM-CAB-PN2h has a carbon accumulation of only 0.7 % after prolonged reaction times. The NM-CAB-PN2h catalyst has smaller active metal particle size, stronger metal-support interaction, and higher surface adsorption oxygen content. This is attributed to the synergistic effect of CAB and N2 plasma. First, during the impregnation process, the amide groups in CAB form strong coordination bonds with Ni2+. Subsequently, the zwitterionic nature of betaine suppresses the agglomeration of metal Ni particles through classical repulsive forces. Additionally, the flexible side chains in CAB reduce steric hindrance, promoting mesopore development and facilitating the entry of Ni particles into the interior of MCM-41 mesopores, thereby enhancing the dispersion of Ni particles within MCM-41. The catalyst precursor modified with CAB was treated with N2 radio frequency plasma. Under the bombardment of high-energy electrons from N2 plasma, nickel particles were generated into small metal particles. At the same time, the high energy carried by the plasma promoted the decomposition of CAB, causing the Ni particles to form strong interactions with the support, preventing the migration and agglomeration of metals in high-temperature environments. In addition, the high-energy electrons generated by the plasma create defects on the surface of the support, releasing the oxygen bound in the support skeleton structure and forming surface-adsorbed oxygen, thereby reducing the formation of carbon deposits. The DRM performances of NM-CAB-PN2h and other nickel-based catalysts were compared in Table 7 . The results showed that NM-CAB-PN2h had excellent catalytic reactivity (CH4 = 82.53 %, CO2 = 85.71 %) at 700 °C. After 20 h reforming reaction, the amount of carbon deposition was only 0.7 %. Therefore, catalysts prepared by CAB and plasma have small volume and strong resistance to carbon deposition. 5 Conclusion In this study, nickel-based catalysts with small size and strong resistance to carbon accumulation were prepared by CAB-coupled radio-frequency plasma. The results show that CAB not only improves the activity of the catalyst, but also enhances the anti-carbon deposition ability of the catalyst. The plasma treatment was then introduced, and the results showed that the synergistic effect between the two could further improve the performance of the catalyst. The conversion of CH4 and CO2 by NM-CAB-PN2h was as high as 82.53 % and 85.71 %, respectively, in a 20 h reforming reaction, with little loss of activity after the reaction. The synergistic effect of CAB with plasma was also confirmed by various characterizations. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the catalysts before and after the reaction showed that the size of the nickel after the reaction was only 7.1 nm, indicating that only a small amount of nickel was sintered during the reaction. TPR and XPS also confirmed this result, and the catalysts prepared with CAB-coupled RF plasma had stronger metal-support interactions and the active metal was less prone to migration. The CO2-TPD spectra showed that the efficiency of NM-CAB-PN2h was higher at the moderately basic sites and that NM-CAB-PN2h was more efficient at the moderately basic sites than CAB-PN2h. The CO2-TPD spectra showed that NM-CAB-PN2h absorbed CO2 more efficiently at the moderately basic sites, which was conducive to improving the reforming reaction activity. The TG-DTA analysis showed that the carbon accumulation of the catalyst was 0.70 %. Compared to NM-C, NM-CAB-PN2h has a higher resistance to carbon deposition. Therefore, the catalysts prepared with CAB-assisted RF plasma showed a significant improvement in both activity and anti-carbon deposition performance. This finding provides strong evidence that structure-directing agent-assisted plasma can improve the performance of catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Carbon deposition is an important cause of rapid deactivation of nickel-based catalysts during dry reforming of methane. Catalyst precursors were synthesized by CAB (cocamidopropyl betaine) assisted impregnation and subsequently activated via calcination (NM-CAB-1/50-C) and RF plasma (NM-CAB-PN2h), respectively. The catalyst was characterized using XRD, CO2-TPD, FTIR, XPS, UV, TEM, H2-TPR and TG-DTA. Compared to NM-C, NM-CAB-1/50-C exhibited an enhancement of 13.14 % and 11.01 % in the initial conversion rates of CH4 and CO2 respectively. The carbon deposition of NM-CAB-1/50-C post-reaction (3.43 %) was markedly lower than that of NM-C (23.38 %), indicating that the CAB improved the catalyst's activity and resistance to carbon deposition to a certain degree. Specifically, NM-CAB-PN2h had the greatest activity and most potent anti-carbon deposition capability among all the catalysts. For NM-CAB-PN2h, the initial conversion rates of CH4 and CO2 attained 82.53 % and 85.71 %, respectively, with a carbon deposition level of merely 0.7 % post-reaction. The characterization results indicated that NM-CAB-PN2h exhibited the smallest nickel particle size (4.2 nm) and the most robust metal-support interaction force. The catalyst demonstrated a significant surface adsorbed oxygen concentration of 7.3 %. This results from the synergistic effect of CAB and N2 plasma, which markedly diminishes the size of active metal particles, amplifies the metal-support contact force, and elevates the alkalinity of the catalytic surface along with the surface-adsorbed oxygen content. Consequently, the catalyst's activity and resistance to carbon deposition were markedly improved.
coredata.dc:title: A strategy of constructing the Ni/MCM-41 catalyst structure with high activity and carbon deposition enhanced by radio frequency plasma coupled with CAB for dry reforming of methane
